ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got a better understanding of the intricacies of the leading addictions in the United States, and how they can impact the economy in different manners. I also got a better understanding about the causes of these addictions, and what possible steps should be implemented to decrease their impact.
You learn a lot about different types of addiction and how economic concepts can be employed to realign incentives and inform policy.
Case studies about addiction
Well balanced overview of health economics with a US focus while also looking cross countries
Economis
I learned about addiction and behavioral economics

I learned many things in this course.  I've always thought about addictions and treatments for them, but never from an economic perspective.  This course taught me to think of addictions within an economic context, not only about the direct costs of an addiction, but the indirect costs incurred by society.  I also learned new forms of the treatment and actions governments can take to curtail the social costs of an addiction, which was quite interesting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I don't think this course can really be improved upon, the way it is taught now is great.
Lots of reading and writing

Strengths: Professor Sindelar is great at picking relevant topics and lecturing about them. It was a great interdisciplinary course for public health and economics topics. All of the topics are interesting and pertinent.

Weaknesses: The assignments were quite long -- lots of reading responses, maybe more than we need for class discussion.
Good course overall
Professor Sindelar is a gem. Truly wants to see her students succeed.
Good class

Strengths: interesting material, Professor was accessible

Weaknesses: it was sometimes difficult to interpret certain forms of feedback

I enjoyed the collaborative aspects of the course, specifically the group projects as well as the discussions in the seminar.  I think the lectures could have been improved with more visuals or graphs.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they want to do a senior economics seminar, that isn't massively math oriented, this is the one to take. It combines economic principles with modern issues that allow you to apply those same economic principles too.
Yes -- great Economics senior seminar!
Yes!

YES YES YES! Great senior ECON class that does not require an overly extensive amount of time outside of the classroom. Paper instead of final. The course is designed so most of the work for the paper will be done far in advance. Professor Sindelar is a gem. Great class!
Yes
Yes: its a great way to learn about behavioral economics

I'd recommend this to any student that would like to think about the economic side of current problems such as opioids or other addictions.  There are many current issues in the course that are relevant.
